original_title: NPP govt won’t honour Sri Lanka’s ISB debt, warns Harsha de Silva
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT — The “top economist” of Sri Lanka’s leftist alliance National People’s Power (NPP) has confirmed that a future NPP government will not honour Sri Lanka’s outstanding international sovereign bond (ISB) debt, according to opposition MP Harsha de Silva.

“That a future JVP/NPP Gov will NOT honour #SriLanka USD 12b ISB debt; first insinuated by their chief econ adviser Prof Anil J at @CeylonChamber now repeated clearly by their top economist Sunil Handunhetti goes to show these guys have absolutely no idea how to run a country,” de Silva said in a tweet on Wednesday January 03.

The MP made this claim after a video went viral online showing Handunneththi, former Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) MP and ex-chair of the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE), casually dismissing Sri Lanka’s obligations to its ISB holders.
If we say we will not payback to ISB holders, they will say 'no worrys Machang'
We will say to IMF, if you want give us money but dont put any conditions
These are lollipop ideas with no practicality.#lka #SriLanka #jvp #කයියෝ pic.twitter.com/7Db3KeRidR

“How did we get stuck in ISBs? Everyone who puts in money for ISBs do so taking the risk involved. They calculate the interest with the risk included. They have already taken the risk from the interest. If we say we’re not paying the ISB debt, they’ll say ‘it’s okay, machang’, because the risk is contained in the interest,” Handunneththi said in the video.

“ISBs are for investing in risky economies. The maturity periods and interests are calculated after a risk analysis. That’s what we have to say to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) too. ‘Give us the loan if you wish to. We will pay it back, but give us a fair amount of time to pay back. We don’t want conditions,” he added.

In his response, MP de Silva, who is the foremost voice for economic policy in the main opposition party the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), said the NPP’s economic advisor Prof Anil Jayasekera had originally made a similar remark, which Handunneththi was now repeating.
This goes to show the NPP has “no idea how to run a country,” he said.
In an interview with EconomyNext in June 2023, de Silva said Sri Lanka’s next election will be a battle of ideologies.
Sri Lanka’s next election a battle of ideologies: Harsha de SilvaSee more

The leftist NPP, a loose alliance dominated by the Marxist-Leninist JVP which has been increasingly critical of the IMF programme, has gained ground in the aftermath of the 2022 crisis and, according to at least one poll, is still ahead of the SJB, the SLPP and President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s one-man United National Party (UNP). Against this backdrop, if President Wickremesinghe were to invite the SJB to come back into the UNP fold – Sri Lanka’s so called ‘grand old party’ which the SJB broke away from – or to form a grand alliance with like minded groups, would the SJB consider it?

“I think we should consider any alliance that is ideologically aligned,” answered de Silva in the June interview, adding, however, that the SJB is in complete disagreement with the president on the alleged partnership with and protection of those accused of corruption, as well as controversial pieces of legislation such as the proposed broadcast regulatory commission act, the anti-terrorism act ant the like.
“These are completely wrong. This is not the Ranil Wickremesinghe that we knew,” he said.
Meanwhile, MP Nalaka Godahewa, a key proponent of the Viyathmaga professional body that backed ex President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has joined forces with the SJB.
Speaking at an SJB press event, Godahewa distanced the Viyathmaga outfit from the discredited policies of Rajapaksa.

Godahewa, speaking to the media with an SJB banner behind him, claimed that Viyathmaga, a body of professionals who endorsed and campaigned for Rajapaksa in the run-up to the 2019 presidential poll, was excluded from key policy decisions.
